column4: Is there a reason why the manual partitioner needs to sanitize my partition table? I hid my NTFS partition for a *reason* - to keep the XP installer from messing with it.
Instead the Ubuntu (kubuntu 8.04) installer decides to shrink the extended partition to perfectly fit the Linux partitions, and deletes my NTFS partition.
if you did something to obscure a partition from the partition table then it's probably gonna get hosed when something else manipulates the partition table.
I set the hidden flag, which changed the partition type to a 'hidden' but still valid entry.

isn't 'hidden partition' a microsoft concept and not actualy a function of standard partition table.  do   fdisk -l /dev/hda  (assuming hda is the disk in question ) and tell us if you see the partition.
that's the problem. Ubuntu deleted the damn thing and then shrunk my extended partition to 'free' the empty space.

If it was just a parition type then it wouldn't delete it.  Unknown partitions are definately left alone. It had to be 'not in the parition' table.  But let me continue to try to find reference, there may be a way out.
the partition in question is a logical partition within an extended partition - but the extended partition has been shrunk to 'free' this 'free space'.
Fedora's variant doesn't do this - all I wanted to do was set the mount points. I didn't want it messing with my partitions in the first place.
don't know what to tell you. I've not seen any paritioners mangle the table unless told to.  I'm guessing you have no backup.
not for the majority of the data, no.
yeah, you could actually allocate to an extended but then you couldn't boot off it anyway.
it's a data partition, not OS (the boot partitions for XP and Linux are elsewhere). :)
you can zap one of the primaries for ubuntu and put in the NTFS to recover your data.   The rude statement "Always backup first" is already ringing in you ears so I won't say it :)
as long as the start and end cylinders are correct you should be able to do it.
how many partitions on that disk now and is one of them an extended?
okay, my table's sane again but I lost my actual XP partition.
thanks for the help - I'm suddenly reminded just why I hate the Intel partition table design, though. :p
